III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4125 Personal possessions; money; clothing;
Section storage space.
Description (1) A licensee shall have a written policy that designates all of the
following:
(c) The method for ensuring that each resident has sufficient
clean, properly fitting, seasonal clothing.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth at the facility is wearing revealing clothing and the youth
feels the clothing is too small and would like new clothes.
Investigation The Complainant was anonymous.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
25, 2025. Youth A reported she has enough clothes and stated
she recently went shopping with Supervisor. Youth A denied
wearing crop tops at the facility and stated “booty shorts” are not
allowed. Youth A described her clothes fitting and never having a
time when at the facility that she did not have adequate,
appropriate sized clothing to wear.
Youth B and Youth C were interviewed face to face,
separately, at the facility on March 25, 2025. They both
reported all the girls at the facility have enough clothes. They both
stated if youth do not have clothes that fit or do not have enough
of something Supervisor will take them shopping to get what is
needed. Youth C denied seeing any youth wear tank tops or
booty shorts. Youth C stated those type of clothes would not be
allowed.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
25, 2025. Staff 1 reported Youth A has adequate clothing that fits.
Staff 1 stated Youth A recently put a pair of jeans on that were too
small, but it was determined the jeans belonged to another youth.
Staff 1 reported if the girls need clothes, they are taken to Clothing
Inc. to get items and will also go to different stores to purchase
bras and underwear.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
25, 2025. Staff 2 reported Youth A has two totes of clothes and
believes the clothing items all fit. Staff 2 stated Youth A’s clothes
were moved out of her room because she was trying to hang
herself. Staff 2 described Youth A ripping her shirt recently trying
to make it smaller and more revealing, but staff intervened. Staff
2 reported Supervisor took Youth A and other youth to Clothing
Inc. last week to purchase more clothing items. Staff 2 stated
recently Youth A took a pair of jeans belonging to another girl at
the house and tried to wear them, but the jeans were too small for
Youth A.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
March 25, 2025. Supervisor stated she went to Clothing Inc. on
March 14 and March 17, 2025, so all the girls could go shopping.
2

Supervisor reported Youth A went on the outing and clothing items
were purchased for Youth A. Supervisor denied Youth A not
having clothes that fit. Supervisor stated Youth A has never
completed a needs request form.
Tour Observation:
Youth A’s clothing was observed to be in two large totes along
with one laundry basket. Youth A’s clothing had been removed
from her bedroom due to Youth A trying to hang herself with the
clothing items.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’s MDHHS clothing inventory sheet dated
1/15/2025. Clothing sheet lists: 1 heavy coat, 1 jacket, 11
sweaters, 2 dresses, 21 shirts, 10 jeans, 7 pants, 7 shorts,
1 bathing suit, 5 pairs of underwear, 8 bras, 1 bathrobe, 1
pajama, 18 socks, 1 pair of sneakers, 1 pair of slippers, 3
pairs of boots, 2 hats/scarfs. There was no identified
clothing needs listed on the inventory sheet.
• Daily log sheets noting where and when youth were off
campus. March 14, 2025, 10am youth to Clothing Inc.
March 17, 2025, 2pm youth to Clothing Inc.
• New Hope Youth Center Admission and Orientation Policy.
Policy states, “Using the MDHHS clothing inventory
checklist, the staff will determine if the youth has enough
seasonal clothing. If it is determined the youth is in need of
clothing the program will purchase the remainder of the
necessary items. Reassessment of clothing needs occurs
at a minimum every 6 months and new clothing items will
be purchases. It is the youth’s responsibility to report any
additional clothing needs throughout their stay by using the
needs request form.”
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews Youth A has enough clothing and clothing that fits.
Technical Assistance:
Technical Assistance was offered to list the youth’s name or
initials that go on an outing. The daily log documented what time
and how many youths went to Clothing Inc. but not the youth’s
name or initials.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149 Resident nutrition.
Section (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible meals
Description daily unless medically contraindicated and documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There is a concern for the food in the home because there was
only a pizza provided for lunch and dinner.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
25, 2025. Youth A reported there is “always enough food,
sometimes even too much.” Youth A described when pizza is
made for lunch or dinner a minimum of three pizzas are made.
Youth A denied there ever being a time where there was not
enough food for all the youth at the facility for any meal.
Youth B and Youth C were interviewed face to face,
separately, at the facility on March 25, 2025. They both
reported there is always enough food for all the girls to eat at
every meal. Both girls described snacks being provided between
meals or fruit and peanut butter and jelly sandwiches if girls are
still hungry after a meal. Youth B and Youth C denied ever having
pizza where only one pizza was provided for every girl for lunch
and dinner. Youth C stated there are always at least three pizzas
provided when pizza is on the menu.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
25, 2025. Staff 1 described if pizza is on the menu at least three
pizzas get made for that meal. Staff 1 stated there are always
multiple pizzas, so the girls have options with toppings. Staff 1
denied ever not having enough food for all the girls at any meal.
Staff 1 reported the same meal would never be provided for lunch
and dinner. Staff 1 stated if a youth is still hungry after eating,
fruit, crackers, salad, or PBJ is always provided.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
25, 2025. Staff 2 reported there is always enough food at every
meal for every girl at the facility. Staff 2 stated he could not recall
any time where the same food was on the menu for lunch and
dinner. Staff 2 described there is always an “abundant amount of
food.” Staff 2 reported when pizza is on the menu multiple pizzas
get made so the girls can pick from cheese, pepperoni, and
another choice.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
March 25, 2025. Supervisor described being the one who
purchases the groceries for the girls at the facility. Supervisor
4

stated much of the grocery shopping is done at Sams Club and
the pizza she purchases comes in a box containing three pizzas.
Supervisor reported she purchases three boxes at a time.
Supervisor stated she often prepares lunch and will make as
many pizzas as needed for the youth. Supervisor described
making up to five pizzas for the youth at the facility for lunch.
Supervisor stated the girls recently went out for pizza and multiple
pizzas were ordered. Supervisor denied there not being enough
food for all the girls to eat a meal. Supervisor reported pizza
would never be listed on the menu for lunch and dinner for the
same day.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the basement where the additional two freezers and
refrigerator, as well as storage of the facility’s food occurred on
March 25, 2025. Both freezers, refrigerator, pantry, cabinets and
shelves were filled with food.
Documents Reviewed:
• March 2025 Menu for the facility. Pizza was listed as a
meal but only for lunch or dinner and never on the same
day. Some of the meals listed on the menu were: lasagna,
walking tacos, sandwich and chips, chicken legs,
hamburgers, pizza, barbeque tips, BLT and chips,
Quesadillas, seafood boil, and roast.
• Little Ceasars receipt dated March 22, 2025. Four large
pizzas, three 2 liters of soda and cheese bread was
ordered.
• New Hope Youth Center Food Services Policy. The policy
outlines the agency will “provide at a minimum 3 nutritious
meals and availability to healthy snack options.” The facility
will provide food portions in accordance with guidelines and
approved meal plans.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, the facility is providing adequate food portions, and the
youth are provided enough food to eat.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
